data.title: Indian Penal Code - Terrorist Act and Hurt

paragraphs.context: (4) Whoever organises or causes to be organised any camp or camps for imparting training in terrorist act, or recruits or causes to be recruited any person or persons for commission of a terrorist act, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than five years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine. (5) Any person who is a member of an organisation which is involved in terrorist act, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine. (6) Whoever voluntarily harbours or conceals, or attempts to harbour or conceal any person knowing that such person has committed a terrorist act shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than three years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine: Provided that this sub-section shall not apply to any case in which the harbour or concealment is by the spouse of the offender. (7) Whoever knowingly possesses any property derived or obtained from commission of any terrorist act or acquired through the commission of any terrorist act shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine. Explanation.—For the removal of doubts, it is hereby declared that the officer not below the rank of Superintendent of Police shall decide whether to register the case under 37 of 1967. this section or under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967.

qas.question: What is the punishment for organising or recruiting for terrorist training camps?

answers.text: punished with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than five years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine

qas.question: What is the punishment for being a member of an organisation involved in a terrorist act?

answers.text: punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine

qas.question: What is the punishment for harbouring or concealing a person who has committed a terrorist act?

answers.text: punished with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than three years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine

qas.question: What is the punishment for knowingly possessing property derived from a terrorist act?

answers.text: punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine

qas.question: Who decides whether a case should be registered under Section 37 of 1967 or the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act?

answers.text: the officer not below the rank of Superintendent of Police

paragraphs.context: 114. Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause Hurt.

qas.question: What is the definition of 'hurt' under Section 114?

answers.text: Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause Hurt

paragraphs.context: (1) Whoever does any act with the intention of thereby causing hurt to any person, or with the knowledge that he is likely thereby to cause hurt to any person, and does thereby cause hurt to any person, is said “voluntarily to cause hurt”. (2) Whoever, except in the case provided for by sub-section (1) of section 122 voluntarily causes hurt, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for voluntarily causing hurt under Section 115?

answers.text: punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both

qas.question: What is the definition of 'voluntarily causing hurt' under Section 115?

answers.text: Whoever does any act with the intention of thereby causing hurt to any person, or with the knowledge that he is likely thereby to cause hurt to any person, and does thereby cause hurt to any person

paragraphs.context: 116. The following kinds of hurt only are designated as “grievous”, namely:–– (a) Emasculation; (b) Permanent privation of the sight of either eye; (c) Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear; (d) Privation of any member or joint; (e) Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint; (f) Permanent disfiguration of the head or face; (g) Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth; (h) Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of fifteen days in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.

qas.question: What are the types of hurt designated as 'grievous' under Section 116?

answers.text: Emasculation; Permanent privation of the sight of either eye; Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear; Privation of any member or joint; Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint; Permanent disfiguration of the head or face; Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth; Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of fifteen days in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits

paragraphs.context: (1) Whoever voluntarily causes hurt, if the hurt which he intends to cause or knows himself to be likely to cause is grievous hurt, and if the hurt which he causes is grievous hurt, is said “voluntarily to cause grievous hurt”.

qas.question: What is the definition of 'voluntarily causing grievous hurt' under Section 117?

answers.text: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt, if the hurt which he intends to cause or knows himself to be likely to cause is grievous hurt, and if the hurt which he causes is grievous hurt

paragraphs.context: Mischief by Affecting Landmarks: Destroying or moving any landmark fixed by a public authority, or making it less useful, carries a punishment of: Imprisonment for up to 1 year, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for mischief affecting landmarks?

answers.text: The punishment for mischief affecting landmarks is imprisonment for up to 1 year, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: In all robbery there is either theft or extortion.

qas.question: What is the basis of robbery?

answers.text: Robbery involves either theft or extortion.

paragraphs.context: Theft is robbery if, in order to the committing of the theft, or in committing the theft, or in carrying away or attempting to carry away property obtained by the theft, the offender, for that end voluntarily causes or attempts to cause to any person death or hurt or wrongful restraint, or fear of instant death or of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint.

qas.question: When does theft become robbery?

answers.text: When the offender causes or attempts to cause death, hurt, wrongful restraint, or fear of instant death, hurt, or wrongful restraint in the process of committing theft.

paragraphs.context: Extortion is robbery if the offender, at the time of committing the extortion, is in the presence of the person put in fear, and commits the extortion by putting that person in fear of instant death, of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint to that person or to some other person, and, by so putting in fear, induces the person so put in fear then and there to deliver up the thing extorted.

qas.question: When does extortion become robbery?

answers.text: When the offender is present and induces fear of instant death, hurt, or wrongful restraint, causing the person to deliver the extorted thing.

paragraphs.context: The offender is said to be present if he is sufficiently near to put the other person in fear of instant death, of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint.

qas.question: What does 'presence' mean in the context of robbery and extortion?

answers.text: Presence means being sufficiently near to put the other person in fear of instant death, hurt, or wrongful restraint.

paragraphs.context: A holds Z down, and fraudulently takes Z’s money and jewels from Z’s clothes, without Z’s consent. Here A has committed theft, and, in order to the committing of that theft, has voluntarily caused wrongful restraint to Z. A has therefore committed robbery.

qas.question: What crime has A committed in this illustration?

answers.text: A has committed robbery, as he caused wrongful restraint while committing theft.

data.title: Legal Obligations to State the Truth and Provide Information

paragraphs.context: Whoever refuses to bind himself by an oath or affirmation to state the truth, when required so to bind himself by a public servant legally competent to require that he shall so bind himself, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for refusing to take an oath or affirmation to state the truth?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being legally bound to state the truth on any subject to any public servant, refuses to answer any question demanded of him touching that subject by such public servant in the exercise of the legal powers of such public servant, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for refusing to answer a question from a public servant when legally bound?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever refuses to sign any statement made by him, when required to sign that statement by a public servant legally competent to require that he shall sign that statement, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to three thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for refusing to sign a statement made to a public servant?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to three thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or affirmation to state the truth on any subject to any public servant or other person authorised by law to administer such oath or affirmation, makes, to such public servant or other person as aforesaid, touching that subject, any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for making a false statement under oath?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever gives to any public servant any information which he knows or believes to be false, intending thereby to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause, such public servant— (a) to do or omit anything which such public servant ought not to do or omit if the true state of facts respecting which such information is given were known by him; or (b) to use the lawful power of such public servant to the injury or annoyance of any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for giving false information to a public servant to cause an omission or annoyance?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: A informs a Magistrate that Z, a police officer, subordinate to such Magistrate, has been guilty of neglect of duty or misconduct, knowing such information to be false, and knowing it to be likely that the information will cause the Magistrate to dismiss Z. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

qas.question: What false information does A give to the Magistrate?

answers.text: Z, a police officer, subordinate to such Magistrate, has been guilty of neglect of duty or misconduct.

qas.question: What does A intend to cause by giving false information to the Magistrate?

answers.text: Knowing it to be likely that the information will cause the Magistrate to dismiss Z.

paragraphs.context: A falsely informs a public servant that Z has contraband salt in a secret place, knowing such information to be false, and knowing that it is likely that the consequence of the information will be a search of Z's premises, attended with annoyance to Z. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

qas.question: What false information does A give to the public servant about Z?

answers.text: Z has contraband salt in a secret place.

qas.question: What is the likely consequence of A's false information about Z?

answers.text: A search of Z's premises, attended with annoyance to Z.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Offences Against the State

paragraphs.context: 162. Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, on any superior officer being in the execution of his office, shall, if such assault be committed in consequence of that abetment be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abetting an assault that is committed on a superior officer in the Army, Navy, or Air Force under Section 162?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 7 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 163. Whoever abets the desertion of any officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abetting the desertion of an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Army, Navy, or Air Force under Section 163?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 2 years, or with a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: 164. Whoever, except as hereinafter excepted, knowing or having reason to believe that an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, has deserted, harbours such officer, soldier, sailor or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine or with both. Exception.—This provision does not extend to the case in which the harbour is given by the spouse of the deserter.

qas.question: What is the punishment for harbouring a deserter in the Army, Navy, or Air Force under Section 164?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 2 years, or with a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: 165. The master or person in charge of a merchant vessel, on board of which any deserter from the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India is concealed, shall, though ignorant of such concealment, be liable to a penalty not exceeding three thousand rupees, if he might have known of such concealment but for some neglect of his duty as such master or person in charge, or but for some want of discipline on board of the vessel.

qas.question: What is the penalty for a merchant vessel master negligently concealing a deserter from the Army, Navy, or Air Force under Section 165?

answers.text: The penalty is a fine not exceeding three thousand rupees.

paragraphs.context: 166. Whoever abets what he knows to be an act of insubordination by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force, of the Government of India, shall, if such act of insubordination be committed in consequence of that abetment, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abetting an act of insubordination in the Army, Navy, or Air Force under Section 166?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 2 years, or with a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: 167. No person subject to the Air Force Act, 1950, the Army Act, 1950 and the Navy Act, 1957, or shall be subject to punishment under this Sanhita for any of the offences defined in this Chapter.

qas.question: Are persons subject to the Air Force Act, Army Act, or Navy Act punishable under this chapter for offences?

answers.text: No, persons subject to these Acts are not punishable under this chapter for offences.

paragraphs.context: 168. Whoever, not being a soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Naval or Air service of the Government of India, wears any garb or carries any token resembling any garb or token used by such a soldier, sailor or airman with the intention that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for wearing a garb or carrying a token resembling that of a soldier, sailor, or airman under Section 168?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 3 months, or a fine of up to 2,000 rupees, or both.

paragraphs.context: 169. For the purposes of this Chapter—(a) “candidate” means a person who has been nominated as a candidate at any election; (b) “electoral right” means the right of a person to stand, or not to stand as, or to withdraw from being, a candidate or to vote or refrain from voting at an election.

qas.question: What is the definition of a candidate and electoral right under Section 169?

answers.text: A candidate is a person nominated at any election, and electoral right is the right to stand, withdraw from being a candidate, or to vote or refrain from voting.

paragraphs.context: 170. (1) Whoever—(i) gives a gratification to any person with the object of inducing him or any other person to exercise any electoral right or of rewarding any person for having exercised any such right; or

qas.question: What is the punishment for giving a gratification to induce or reward someone for exercising their electoral right under Section 170?

answers.text: The punishment is defined in the full text of Section 170, but it is related to bribery for influencing electoral rights.

paragraphs.context: Dishonestly Preventing Debt Payment: A person who dishonestly or fraudulently prevents a debt or demand from being made available for the payment of his debts or another person's debts, shall be punished with: Imprisonment for up to 2 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for dishonestly preventing debt payment?

answers.text: The punishment for dishonestly preventing debt payment is imprisonment for up to 2 years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever intentionally puts any person in fear of any injury to that person, or to any other, and thereby dishonestly induces the person so put in fear to deliver to any person any property, or valuable security or anything signed or sealed which may be converted into a valuable security, commits extortion.

qas.question: What constitutes extortion?

answers.text: Intentionally putting any person in fear of injury and dishonestly inducing them to deliver property, security, or anything signed or sealed.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits extortion shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing extortion?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts any person in fear, or attempts to put any person in fear, of any injury, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for putting a person in fear to commit extortion?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts or attempts to put any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for putting a person in fear of death or grievous hurt during extortion?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits extortion by putting any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for extortion involving fear of death or grievous hurt?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts or attempts to put any person in fear of an accusation, against that person or any other, of having committed, or attempted to commit, an offence punishable with death or with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for putting a person in fear of an accusation of serious crimes during extortion?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits extortion by putting any person in fear of an accusation against that person or any other, of having committed or attempted to commit any offence punishable with death, or with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, or of having attempted to induce any other person to commit such offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for extortion involving a fear of serious accusation or inducement to commit serious crimes?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

data.title: Section 357: Neglect of Duty by a Person Bound by a Lawful Contract

paragraphs.context: Punishment for Omission: Whoever is legally bound by a contract to attend to or supply the needs of a person who is helpless, due to youth, unsoundness of mind, or a disease or bodily weakness, and voluntarily omits to perform that duty, shall face: Imprisonment (either description) for up to three months, or Fine up to ₹5,000, or Both imprisonment and fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for neglecting a duty under a lawful contract for a helpless person?

answers.text: Imprisonment (either description) for up to three months, or Fine up to ₹5,000, or Both imprisonment and fine.

paragraphs.context: Mischief Involving Rail, Aircraft, or Vessels: Destruction or Unsafe Rendering of Transport Infrastructure: If someone commits mischief to destroy or make unsafe any rail, aircraft, or vessel (of 20 tons or more), the punishment is: Imprisonment for up to 10 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for mischief involving rail, aircraft, or vessels of 20 tons or more?

answers.text: The punishment for mischief involving rail, aircraft, or vessels of 20 tons or more is imprisonment for up to 10 years, a fine, or both.

data.title: Offences Related to False Claims, False Charges, Harbouring Offenders

paragraphs.context: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly, or with intent to injure or annoy any person, makes in a Court any claim which he knows to be false, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for making a false claim in a Court with fraudulent intent?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever fraudulently obtains a decree or order against any person for a sum not due, or for a larger sum than is due or for any property or interest in property to which he is not entitled, or fraudulently causes a decree or order to be executed against any person after it has been satisfied or for anything in respect of which it has been satisfied, or fraudulently suffers or permits any such act to be done in his name, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for fraudulently obtaining a decree or order for an incorrect amount or property?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, with intent to cause injury to any person, institutes or causes to be instituted any criminal proceeding against that person, or falsely charges any person with having committed an offence, knowing that there is no just or lawful ground for such proceeding or charge against that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine which may extend to two lakh rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for falsely charging someone with a crime?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine which may extend to two lakh rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, with intent to cause injury to any person, institutes or causes to be instituted any criminal proceeding against that person, or falsely charges any person with having committed an offence, knowing that there is no just or lawful ground for such proceeding or charge against that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for falsely charging someone with a serious offence punishable with death or life imprisonment?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whenever an offence has been committed, whoever harbours or conceals a person whom he knows or has reason to believe to be the offender, with the intention of screening him from legal punishment shall,— (a) if the offence is punishable with death, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine; (b) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine; (c) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment which may extend to one year, and not to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of the description provided for the offence for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term of imprisonment provided for the offence, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for harbouring or concealing an offender knowing they have committed a punishable offence?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: This section shall not extend to any case in which the harbour or concealment is by the spouse of the offender.

qas.question: Is there an exception for a spouse harbouring or concealing an offender?

answers.text: Yes, this section shall not extend to any case in which the harbour or concealment is by the spouse of the offender.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Offences Relating to Elections

paragraphs.context: 170. (ii) accepts either for himself or for any other person any gratification as a reward for exercising any such right or for inducing or attempting to induce any other person to exercise any such right, commits the offence of bribery: Provided that a declaration of public policy or a promise of public action shall not be an offence under this section.

qas.question: What is the offence committed by accepting gratification as a reward for exercising an electoral right or inducing others to do so under Section 170?

answers.text: The offence committed is bribery.

paragraphs.context: 170. (2) A person who offers, or agrees to give, or offers or attempts to procure, a gratification shall be deemed to give a gratification. (3) A person who obtains or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain a gratification shall be deemed to accept a gratification, and a person who accepts a gratification as a motive for doing what he does not intend to do, or as a reward for doing what he has not done, shall be deemed to have accepted the gratification as a reward.

qas.question: What does Section 170 say about offering or accepting gratification?

answers.text: A person offering or attempting to offer gratification is deemed to have given it, and a person accepting it is deemed to have accepted it, even if the acceptance is for doing something not intended or as a reward for something not done.

paragraphs.context: 171. (1) Whoever voluntarily interferes or attempts to interfere with the free exercise of any electoral right commits the offence of undue influence at an election. (2) Without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub-section (1), whoever—(a) threatens any candidate or voter, or any person in whom a candidate or voter is interested, with injury of any kind; or (b) induces or attempts to induce a candidate or voter to believe that he or any person in whom he is interested will become or will be rendered an object of Divine displeasure or of spiritual censure, shall be deemed to interfere with the free exercise of the electoral right of such candidate or voter, within the meaning of sub-section (1). (3) A declaration of public policy or a promise of public action or the mere exercise or a legal right without intent to interfere with an electoral right, shall not be deemed to be interference within the meaning of this section.

qas.question: What does Section 171 define as the offence of undue influence during an election?

answers.text: The offence of undue influence is committed by interfering with the free exercise of electoral rights, including threats or inducements related to spiritual or personal harm.

paragraphs.context: 172. Whoever at an election applies for a voting paper on votes in the name of any other person, whether living or dead, or in a fictitious name, or who having voted once at such election applies at the same election for a voting paper in his own name, and whoever abets, procures or attempts to procure the voting by any person in any such way, commits the offence of personation at an election: Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to a person who has been authorised to vote as proxy for an elector under any law for the time being in force in so far as he votes as a proxy for such elector.

qas.question: What constitutes the offence of personation at an election under Section 172?

answers.text: The offence of personation involves applying for a voting paper in someone else's name or in a fictitious name, or voting more than once under the same identity.

paragraphs.context: 173. Whoever commits the offence of bribery shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both: Provided that bribery by treating shall be punished with fine only. Explanation.—“Treating” means that form of bribery where the gratification consists in food, drink, entertainment, or provision.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing the offence of bribery under Section 173?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 1 year, a fine, or both. Bribery by treating is punished with only a fine.

paragraphs.context: 174. Whoever commits the offence of undue influence or personation at an election shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing the offence of undue influence or personation at an election under Section 174?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 1 year, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: 175. Whoever with intent to affect the result of an election makes or publishes any statement purporting to be a statement of fact which is false and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, in relation to the personal character or conduct of any candidate shall be punished with fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for publishing a false statement to affect the result of an election under Section 175?

answers.text: The punishment is a fine.

paragraphs.context: Illustrations. (a) The sections in this Sanhita, which contain definitions of offences, do not express that a child under seven years of age cannot commit such offences; but the definitions are to be understood subject to the general exception which provides that nothing shall be an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.

qas.question: Can a child under seven years of age be held guilty of an offence as per this Sanhita?

answers.text: No, nothing shall be an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.

paragraphs.context: (b) A, a police officer, without warrant, apprehends Z, who has committed murder. Here A is not guilty of the offence of wrongful confinement; for he was bound by law to apprehend Z, and therefore the case falls within the general exception which provides that 'nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is bound by law to do it'.

qas.question: Why is a police officer not guilty of wrongful confinement when apprehending a murderer without a warrant?

answers.text: The police officer is not guilty because he was bound by law to apprehend the murderer, and the act falls within the general exception that 'nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is bound by law to do it'.

paragraphs.context: (3) When property is in the possession of a person’s spouse, clerk or servant, on account of that person, it is in that person’s possession within the meaning of this Sanhita.

qas.question: How is property possession interpreted in the context of this Sanhita?

answers.text: When property is in the possession of a person’s spouse, clerk or servant, on account of that person, it is considered to be in that person’s possession.

paragraphs.context: (5) When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone.

qas.question: What happens when a criminal act is committed by several persons with a common intention?

answers.text: Each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone.

paragraphs.context: (6) Whenever an act, which is criminal only by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention, is done by several persons, each of such persons who joins in the act with such knowledge or intention is liable for the act in the same manner as if the act were done by him alone with that knowledge or intention.

qas.question: What is the liability of persons joining in a criminal act requiring criminal knowledge or intention?

answers.text: Each of such persons who joins in the act with such knowledge or intention is liable for the act in the same manner as if the act were done by him alone with that knowledge or intention.

paragraphs.context: CHAPTER II OF PUNISHMENTS: 4. The punishments to which offenders are liable under the provisions of this Sanhita are— (a) Death; (b) Imprisonment for life; (c) Imprisonment, which is of two descriptions, namely: (1) Rigorous, that is, with hard labour; (2) Simple; (d) Forfeiture of property; (e) Fine; (f) Community Service.

qas.question: What are the types of punishments provided under this Sanhita?

answers.text: Death, Imprisonment for life, Rigorous imprisonment, Simple imprisonment, Forfeiture of property, Fine, and Community Service.

paragraphs.context: Commutation of sentence: 5. The appropriate Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute any punishment under this Sanhita to any other punishment in accordance with section 474 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023. Explanation: For the purposes of this section the expression 'appropriate Government' means,— (a) in cases where the sentence is a sentence of death or is for an offence against any law relating to a matter to which the executive power of the Union extends, the Central Government; and (b) in cases where the sentence (whether of death or not) is for an offence against any law relating to a matter to which the executive power of the State extends, the Government of the State within which the offender is sentenced.

qas.question: Who has the authority to commute a sentence under this Sanhita?

answers.text: The appropriate Government, which can be either the Central Government or the State Government depending on the case.

qas.question: What does the 'appropriate Government' refer to in the context of commutation of sentences?

answers.text: In cases where the sentence is of death or related to a matter under the Union’s executive power, it is the Central Government; in cases related to the State's executive power, it is the Government of the State.

paragraphs.context: Fractions of terms of punishment: 6. In calculating fractions of terms of punishment, imprisonment for life shall be reckoned as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years unless otherwise provided.

qas.question: How is imprisonment for life calculated in terms of punishment fractions?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life is reckoned as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years unless otherwise provided.

paragraphs.context: 7. In every case in which an offender is punishable with imprisonment which may be of either description, it shall be competent to the Court which sentences such offender to direct in the sentence that such imprisonment shall be wholly rigorous, or that such imprisonment shall be wholly simple, or that any part of such imprisonment shall be rigorous and the rest simple.

qas.question: What discretion does the Court have in cases of imprisonment of either description?

answers.text: The Court may direct that imprisonment shall be wholly rigorous, wholly simple, or partly rigorous and partly simple.

paragraphs.context: Where the victim consents to the capture of the images or any act, but not to their dissemination to third persons and where such image or act is disseminated, such dissemination shall be considered an offence under this section.

qas.question: What is considered an offence regarding dissemination of images under this section?

answers.text: Dissemination of images or acts without the victim's consent to third persons.

paragraphs.context: Any man who follows a woman and contacts, or attempts to contact such woman to foster personal interaction repeatedly despite a clear indication of disinterest by such woman; or monitors the use by a woman of the internet, e-mail or any other form of electronic communication, commits the offence of stalking.

qas.question: What actions constitute the offence of stalking?

answers.text: Following a woman and contacting or attempting to contact her despite a clear indication of disinterest, or monitoring her use of the internet, e-mail or any other form of electronic communication.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits the offence of stalking shall be punished on first conviction with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine; and be punished on a second or subsequent conviction, with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for stalking on the first conviction?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, intending to insult the modesty of any woman, utters any words, makes any sound or gesture, or exhibits any object in any form, intending that such word or sound shall be heard, or that such gesture or object shall be seen, by such woman, or intrudes upon the privacy of such woman, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and also with fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for intending to insult the modesty of a woman?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and also with fine.

paragraphs.context: Where the death of a woman is caused by any burns or bodily injury or occurs otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven years of her marriage and it is shown that soon before her death she was subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or any relative of her husband for, or in connection with, any demand for dowry, such death shall be called 'dowry death', and such husband or relative shall be deemed to have caused her death.

qas.question: What is the definition of 'dowry death'?

answers.text: The death of a woman caused by burns or bodily injury, or occurring otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven years of her marriage, and it is shown that she was subjected to cruelty or harassment for dowry by her husband or his relatives.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits dowry death shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than seven years but which may extend to imprisonment for life.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing dowry death?

answers.text: Imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than seven years but which may extend to imprisonment for life.

paragraphs.context: Every man who by deceit causes any woman who is not lawfully married to him to believe that she is lawfully married to him and to cohabit or have sexual intercourse with him in that belief, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for deceitfully inducing a woman to believe she is lawfully married?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void by reason of its taking place during the life of such husband or wife, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for marrying again during the lifetime of a spouse?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Dishonest or Fraudulent Transfer of Property: Anyone who dishonestly or fraudulently removes, conceals, delivers, or transfers property without adequate consideration, intending to prevent the distribution of that property according to law among creditors, shall be punished with: Imprisonment for 6 months to 2 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for dishonest or fraudulent transfer of property?

answers.text: The punishment for dishonest or fraudulent transfer of property is imprisonment for 6 months to 2 years, a fine, or both.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Assault and Criminal Force Explanation

paragraphs.context: Explanation.—Mere words do not amount to an assault. But the words which a person uses may give to his gestures or preparation such a meaning as may make those gestures or preparations amount to an assault. Illustrations. (a) A shakes his fist at Z, intending or knowing it to be likely that he may thereby cause Z to believe that A is about to strike Z. A has committed an assault. (b) A begins to unloose the muzzle of a ferocious dog, intending or knowing it to be likely that he may thereby cause Z to believe that he is about to cause the dog to attack Z. A has committed an assault upon Z. (c) A takes up a stick, saying to Z, “I will give you a beating”. Here, though the words used by A could in no case amount to an assault, and though the mere gesture, unaccompanied by any other circumstances, might not amount to an assault, the gesture explained by the words may amount to an assault.

qas.question: What role do words play in an assault under Section 130?

answers.text: Words, when combined with gestures or preparations, can make those gestures or preparations amount to an assault.

qas.question: What happens if someone shakes their fist at another, intending to cause apprehension of being struck under Section 130?

answers.text: It is considered assault, as the gesture is likely to cause the person to believe they are about to be struck.

qas.question: What happens if someone unlooses a ferocious dog's muzzle, intending to cause fear in another person under Section 130?

answers.text: It is considered assault, as the gesture is likely to make the person believe the dog will attack them.

qas.question: What happens if someone takes up a stick and threatens to beat another person under Section 130?

answers.text: It is considered assault, as the gesture combined with words may cause the person to apprehend a beating.

paragraphs.context: Punishment: Cheating by personation is punishable by imprisonment for up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for cheating by personation?

answers.text: The punishment for cheating by personation is imprisonment for up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits the offence under section 88 without the consent of the woman, whether the woman is quick with child or not, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for causing a miscarriage without the woman's consent?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, with intent to cause the miscarriage of a woman with child, does any act which causes the death of such woman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. Where the act is done without the consent of the woman, shall be punishable either with imprisonment for life, or with the punishment specified in said sub-section.

qas.question: What is the punishment for causing the death of a woman while intending to cause a miscarriage?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment if the act is done without the consent of the woman?

answers.text: Imprisonable either with imprisonment for life, or with the punishment specified in said sub-section.

paragraphs.context: Whoever before the birth of any child does any act with the intention of thereby preventing that child from being born alive or causing it to die after its birth, and does by such act prevent that child from being born alive, or causes it to die after its birth, shall, if such act be not caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the mother, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for preventing a child from being born alive or causing it to die after birth?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever does any act under such circumstances, that if he thereby caused death he would be guilty of culpable homicide, and does by such act cause the death of a quick unborn child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for causing the death of a quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever being the father or mother of a child under the age of twelve years, or having the care of such child, shall expose or leave such child in any place with the intention of wholly abandoning such child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abandoning a child under the age of twelve years?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, by secretly burying or otherwise disposing of the dead body of a child whether such child die before or after or during its birth, intentionally conceals or endeavours to conceal the birth of such child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for concealing the birth of a child by secretly disposing of the body?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever hires, employs or engages any child to commit an offence shall be punished with imprisonment of either description which shall not be less than three years but which may extend to ten years and with fine; and if the offence be committed shall also be punished with the punishment provided for that offence as if the offence has been committed by such person himself.

qas.question: What is the punishment for hiring or employing a child to commit an offence?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description which shall not be less than three years but which may extend to ten years and with fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, by any means whatsoever, induces any child to go from any place or to do any act with intent that such child may be, or knowing that it is likely that such child will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person shall be punishable with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for inducing a child with intent to force or seduce them to illicit intercourse?

answers.text: Imprisonment which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any child under the age of ten years with the intention of taking dishonestly any movable property from the person of such child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for kidnapping a child under ten years with intent to steal from them?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

data.title: Punishments and Provisions for House-Trespass and Related Offenses

paragraphs.context: Punishments for Lurking House-Trespass or Housebreaking with Grievous Harm: Grievous Hurt or Attempt to Cause Death: If a person, while committing lurking house-trespass or housebreaking, causes grievous hurt to someone or attempts to cause death or grievous hurt, the punishment is: Imprisonment for life, or Imprisonment for a term up to 10 years, along with a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for causing grievous hurt or attempting to cause death or grievous hurt during lurking house-trespass or housebreaking?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life, or Imprisonment for a term up to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: Grievous Hurt or Attempt to Cause Death (After Sunset and Before Sunrise): If the offense occurs after sunset and before sunrise, and the person voluntarily causes or attempts to cause death or grievous hurt, everyone involved in the offense will face: Imprisonment for life, or Imprisonment for a term up to 10 years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment if grievous hurt or attempt to cause death occurs after sunset and before sunrise during house-trespass or housebreaking?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life, or Imprisonment for a term up to 10 years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: House-Trespass to Commit Other Offenses: Section 332 outlines the punishments for house-trespass with the intent to commit another offense: (a) Punishable with death: Imprisonment for life, or Rigorous imprisonment for up to 10 years, and a fine. (b) Punishable with life imprisonment: Imprisonment for a term up to 10 years, and a fine. (c) Punishable with imprisonment: Imprisonment for up to 2 years, and a fine. If the intended offense is theft, the imprisonment term may extend to 7 years.

qas.question: What is the punishment for house-trespass to commit another offense that is punishable with death?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life, or Rigorous imprisonment for up to 10 years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for house-trespass to commit another offense punishable with life imprisonment?

answers.text: Imprisonment for a term up to 10 years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for house-trespass to commit another offense punishable with imprisonment?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to 2 years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Punishments for House-Trespass with Preparation for Harm: Preparation for Causing Harm: If house-trespass is committed with preparations for: Causing hurt, Assaulting, Wrongfully restraining, Instilling fear of harm or restraint, The punishment is: Imprisonment for up to 7 years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for house-trespass committed with preparations for causing harm?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to 7 years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Punishments for Breaking Open or Unfastening Receptacles: Section 334 outlines the penalties for breaking open or unfastening closed receptacles: Dishonestly or with intent to commit mischief: Breaking or unfastening a closed receptacle (that may contain property or that the person believes to contain property) results in: Imprisonment for up to 2 years, or a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for breaking open or unfastening a closed receptacle dishonestly or with intent to commit mischief?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to 2 years, or a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Being entrusted with a closed receptacle: If a person, without authority, dishonestly or with intent to commit mischief, breaks open or unfastens a receptacle they were entrusted with, the punishment is: Imprisonment for up to 3 years, or a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for breaking open or unfastening a receptacle one was entrusted with, without authority, with intent to commit mischief?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to 3 years, or a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Offenses Related to Making False Documents: Section 335 defines the offense of making false documents: A person commits making a false document or electronic record if they: Dishonestly or fraudulently: Make, sign, seal, or execute a document or part of a document. Make or transmit any electronic record or part of it. Affix an electronic signature on any electronic record. Make any mark denoting the execution of a document or the authenticity of the electronic signature. The intent is to cause the belief that the document, electronic record, or signature was made, signed, sealed, executed, transmitted, or affixed by the authorized person or authority.

qas.question: What is the offense related to making false documents or electronic records?

answers.text: Dishonestly or fraudulently making, signing, sealing, or executing a document or part of a document, transmitting an electronic record, affixing an electronic signature, or making a mark denoting execution or authenticity.

paragraphs.context: There is no right of private defence,–– (a) against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done, or attempted to be done, by a public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office, though that act, may not be strictly justifiable by law; (b) against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done, or attempted to be done, by the direction of a public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office, though that direction may not be strictly justifiable by law; (c) in cases in which there is time to have recourse to the protection of the public authorities.

qas.question: When is there no right of private defence against acts of public servants?

answers.text: Against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done, or attempted to be done, by a public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office.

qas.question: Is there a right of private defence if there is time to have recourse to public authorities?

answers.text: No, there is no right of private defence in cases in which there is time to have recourse to the protection of the public authorities.

paragraphs.context: The right of private defence in no case extends to the inflicting of more harm than it is necessary to inflict for the purpose of defence.

qas.question: Does the right of private defence allow for excessive harm?

answers.text: No, the right of private defence in no case extends to the inflicting of more harm than it is necessary to inflict for the purpose of defence.

paragraphs.context: A person is not deprived of the right of private defence against an act done, or attempted to be done, by a public servant, as such, unless he knows or has reason to believe, that the person doing the act is such public servant.

qas.question: When is a person deprived of the right of private defence against a public servant?

answers.text: If he knows or has reason to believe, that the person doing the act is such public servant.

paragraphs.context: The right of private defence of the body extends, under the restrictions specified in section 37, to the voluntary causing of death or of any other harm to the assailant, if the offence which occasions the exercise of the right be of any of the descriptions hereinafter enumerated, namely: (a) such an assault as may reasonably cause the apprehension that death will otherwise be the consequence of such assault; (b) such an assault as may reasonably cause the apprehension that grievous hurt will otherwise be the consequence of such assault; (c) an assault with the intention of committing rape; (d) an assault with the intention of gratifying unnatural lust; (e) an assault with the intention of kidnapping or abducting; (f) an assault with the intention of wrongfully confining a person, under circumstances which may reasonably cause him to apprehend that he will be unable to have recourse to the public authorities for his release; (g) an act of throwing or administering acid or an attempt to throw or administer acid which may reasonably cause the apprehension that grievous hurt will otherwise be the consequence of such act.

qas.question: When does the right of private defence of the body extend to causing death?

answers.text: If the offence which occasions the exercise of the right includes assaults that cause apprehension of death, grievous hurt, or involve rape, kidnapping, wrongful confinement, or acts like administering acid.

qas.question: Does the right of private defence extend to an assault with the intention of committing rape?

answers.text: Yes, the right of private defence extends to an assault with the intention of committing rape.

paragraphs.context: The right of private defence of the body commences as soon as a reasonable apprehension of danger to the body arises from an attempt or threat to commit the offence though the offence may not have been committed; and it continues as long as such apprehension of danger to the body continues.

qas.question: When does the right of private defence of the body commence and continue?

answers.text: It commences as soon as a reasonable apprehension of danger to the body arises from an attempt or threat to commit the offence and continues as long as such apprehension continues.

paragraphs.context: The right of private defence of property extends, under the restrictions specified in section 37, to the voluntary causing of death or of any other harm to the wrong-doer, if the offence, the committing of which, or the attempting to commit which, occasions the exercise of the right, be an offence of any of the descriptions hereinafter enumerated, namely: (a) robbery; (b) house-breaking after sunset and before sunrise; (c) mischief by fire or any explosive substance committed on any building, tent or vessel, which building, tent or vessel is used as a human dwelling, or as a place for the custody of property; (d) theft, mischief, or house-trespass, under such circumstances as may reasonably cause apprehension that death or grievous hurt will be the consequence, if such right of private defence is not exercised.

qas.question: When does the right of private defence of property extend to causing death?

answers.text: If the offence occasions the exercise of the right and involves robbery, house-breaking after sunset and before sunrise, mischief by fire, or theft under circumstances causing apprehension of death or grievous hurt.

paragraphs.context: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes the apprehension of death, the defender be so situated that he cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, his right of private defence extends to the running of that risk.

qas.question: Does the right of private defence extend to risking harm to an innocent person?

answers.text: Yes, if the defender cannot effectually exercise that right without risking harm to an innocent person.

paragraphs.context: A is attacked by a mob who attempt to murder him. He cannot effectually exercise his right of private defence without firing on the mob, and he cannot fire without risk of harming young children who are mingled with the mob. A commits no offence if by so firing he harms any of the children.

qas.question: Why does A not commit an offence for harming children while defending himself against a mob?

answers.text: Because A could not effectually exercise his right of private defence without risking harm to the children.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Kidnapping or Abducting for Exploitation or Murder

paragraphs.context: (iii) exposing or exhibiting, with the object of obtaining or extorting alms, any sore, wound, injury, deformity or disease, whether of himself or of any other person or of an animal; (iv) using such child as an exhibit for the purpose of soliciting or receiving alms.

qas.question: What is prohibited under Section 139(iii) and (iv) regarding the use of children for begging?

answers.text: It is prohibited to expose or exhibit any sore, wound, injury, deformity, or disease to extort alms or use a child as an exhibit to solicit or receive alms.

paragraphs.context: 140. (1) Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person in order that such person may be murdered or may be so disposed of as to be put in danger of being murdered, shall be punished with imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. Illustrations. (a) A kidnaps Z from India, intending or knowing it to be likely that Z may be sacrificed to an idol. A has committed the offence defined in this section. (b) A forcibly carries or entices B away from his home in order that B may be murdered. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

qas.question: What is the punishment for kidnapping or abducting someone to be murdered or put in danger of murder under Section 140?

answers.text: The punishment is life imprisonment or rigorous imprisonment for up to ten years, along with a fine.

qas.question: What are the two examples of kidnapping given in the Illustrations under Section 140?

answers.text: The examples are: (a) kidnapping for a sacrifice to an idol and (b) forcibly carrying someone away to be murdered.

paragraphs.context: 140. (2) Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person or keeps a person in detention after such kidnapping or abduction, and threatens to cause death or hurt to such person, or by his conduct gives rise to a reasonable apprehension that such person may be put to death or hurt, or causes hurt or death to such person in order to compel the Government or any foreign State or international inter-governmental organisation or any other person to do or abstain from doing any act or to pay a ransom, shall be punishable with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for kidnapping or abduction to force someone to act under threat of death or hurt under Section 140(2)?

answers.text: The punishment is death or life imprisonment, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 140. (3) Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person with intent to cause that person to be secretly and wrongfully confined, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for kidnapping or abduction with the intent to secretly and wrongfully confine a person under Section 140(3)?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to seven years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 140. (4) Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person in order that such person may be subjected, or may be so disposed of as to be put in danger of being subjected to grievous hurt, or slavery, or to the unnatural lust of any person, or knowing it to be likely that such person will be so subjected or disposed of, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for kidnapping or abduction with the intent to subject someone to grievous hurt, slavery, or unnatural lust under Section 140(4)?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to ten years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: Wrongfully concealing or keeping in confinement, kidnapped or abducted person. 142. Whoever, knowing that any person has been kidnapped or has been abducted, wrongfully conceals or confines such person, shall be punished in the same manner as if he had kidnapped or abducted such person with the same intention or knowledge, or for the same purpose as that with or for which he conceals or detains such person in confinement.

qas.question: What is the punishment for wrongfully concealing or keeping a kidnapped or abducted person under Section 142?

answers.text: The punishment is the same as for kidnapping or abduction, with the same intention or purpose.

paragraphs.context: Trafficking of person. 143. (1) Whoever, for the purpose of exploitation recruits, transports, harbours, transfers, or receives a person or persons, by— (a) using threats; or (b) using force, or any other form of coercion; or (c) by abduction; or (d) by practising fraud, or deception; or (e) by abuse of power; or

qas.question: What are the means of trafficking as mentioned in Section 143?

answers.text: Trafficking can be done using threats, force, coercion, abduction, fraud, deception, or abuse of power.

paragraphs.context: A person abets the doing of a thing, who— (a) instigates any person to do that thing; (b) engages with one or more other person or persons in any conspiracy for the doing of that thing, if an act or illegal omission takes place in pursuance of that conspiracy, and in order to the doing of that thing; (c) intentionally aids, by any act or illegal omission, the doing of that thing.

qas.question: Who is considered to abet the doing of a thing?

answers.text: A person who instigates any person to do that thing; engages in conspiracy for the doing of that thing, if an act or illegal omission takes place; or intentionally aids, by any act or illegal omission, the doing of that thing.

paragraphs.context: A person who, by wilful misrepresentation, or by wilful concealment of a material fact which he is bound to disclose, voluntarily causes or procures, or attempts to cause or procure, a thing to be done, is said to instigate the doing of that thing.

qas.question: What constitutes instigating the doing of a thing?

answers.text: Wilful misrepresentation or wilful concealment of a material fact which he is bound to disclose, and voluntarily causing, procuring, or attempting to procure a thing to be done.

paragraphs.context: A, a public officer, is authorised by a warrant from a Court to apprehend Z. B, knowing that fact and also that C is not Z, wilfully represents to A that C is Z, and thereby intentionally causes A to apprehend C. Here B abets by instigation the apprehension of C.

qas.question: How does B abet the apprehension of C?

answers.text: By wilfully representing to A that C is Z, thereby intentionally causing A to apprehend C.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, either prior to or at the time of the commission of an act, does anything in order to facilitate the commission of that act, and thereby facilitates the commission thereof, is said to aid the doing of that act.

qas.question: When is a person said to aid the doing of an act?

answers.text: When they do anything, either prior to or at the time of the commission of an act, to facilitate the commission of that act.

paragraphs.context: To constitute the offence of abetment it is not necessary that the act abetted should be committed, or that the effect requisite to constitute the offence should be caused.

qas.question: Is it necessary for the act abetted to be committed to constitute the offence of abetment?

answers.text: No, it is not necessary that the act abetted should be committed.

paragraphs.context: A instigates B to murder C. B refuses to do so. A is guilty of abetting B to commit murder.

qas.question: Is A guilty of abetment if B refuses to murder C after being instigated?

answers.text: Yes, A is guilty of abetting B to commit murder.

paragraphs.context: A, with a guilty intention, abets a child or a person of unsound mind to commit an act which would be an offence, if committed by a person capable by law of committing an offence, and having the same intention as A. Here A, whether the act be committed or not, is guilty of abetting an offence.

qas.question: Is A guilty of abetment if he instigates a child or a person of unsound mind to commit an offence?

answers.text: Yes, A is guilty of abetting an offence, whether the act is committed or not.

paragraphs.context: A instigates B to set fire to a dwelling-house. B, in consequence of his unsoundness of mind, being incapable of knowing the nature of the act, sets fire to the house in consequence of A’s instigation. B has committed no offence, but A is guilty of abetting the offence of setting fire to a dwelling-house, and is liable to the punishment provided for that offence.

qas.question: Is A guilty of abetment if B, an unsound person, sets fire to a house due to A's instigation?

answers.text: Yes, A is guilty of abetting the offence of setting fire to a dwelling-house.

paragraphs.context: The abetment of an offence being an offence, the abetment of such an abetment is also an offence.

qas.question: Is the abetment of an abetment considered an offence?

answers.text: Yes, the abetment of an abetment is also an offence.

paragraphs.context: A instigates B to instigate C to murder Z. B accordingly instigates C to murder Z, and C commits that offence in consequence of B’s instigation. B is liable to be punished for his offence with the punishment for murder; and, as A instigated B to commit the offence, A is also liable to the same punishment.

qas.question: What is the liability of A if he instigates B to instigate C to commit murder?

answers.text: A is liable to the same punishment as B, who is punished for murder.

paragraphs.context: It is not necessary to the commission of the offence of abetment by conspiracy that the abettor should concert the offence with the person who commits it. It is sufficient if he engages in the conspiracy in pursuance of which the offence is committed.

qas.question: Is it necessary for the abettor to conspire directly with the person committing the offence?

answers.text: No, it is sufficient if the abettor engages in the conspiracy in pursuance of which the offence is committed.

paragraphs.context: A concerts with B a plan for poisoning Z. It is agreed that A shall administer the poison. B then explains the plan to C mentioning that a third person is to administer the poison, but without mentioning A’s name. C agrees to procure the poison, and procures and delivers it to B for the purpose of its being used in the manner explained. A administers the poison; Z dies in consequence. Here, though A and C have not conspired together, yet C has been engaged in the conspiracy in pursuance of which Z has been murdered. C has therefore committed the offence defined in this section and is liable to the punishment for murder.

qas.question: Is C liable for murder if he procures poison without knowing A’s identity but knowing its purpose?

answers.text: Yes, C is liable to the punishment for murder as he engaged in the conspiracy.

paragraphs.context: Dishonest or Fraudulent Concealment or Removal: Anyone who dishonestly or fraudulently conceals or removes any property of themselves or another person, or assists in such concealment or removal, or dishonestly releases any demand or claim they are entitled to, shall be punished with: Imprisonment for up to 3 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for dishonest or fraudulent concealment or removal of property?

answers.text: The punishment for dishonest or fraudulent concealment or removal of property is imprisonment for up to 3 years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Mischief Leading to Loss/Damage of Property: If mischief causes loss or damage to property (including government or local authority property), the punishment is imprisonment up to 1 year, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for mischief leading to loss or damage of property?

answers.text: The punishment for mischief leading to loss or damage of property is imprisonment up to 1 year, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: A, believing in good faith that Z’s property is his, takes it. Since A lacks dishonest intent, he does not commit theft.

qas.question: Why does A not commit theft if he takes Z’s property believing in good faith that it is his?

answers.text: Because A lacks dishonest intent, he does not commit theft.

paragraphs.context: This Act may be called the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023. It shall come into force on such date as the Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, appoint, and different dates may be appointed for different provisions of this Sanhita. Every person shall be liable to punishment under this Sanhita and not otherwise for every act or omission contrary to the provisions thereof, of which he shall be guilty within India. Any person liable, by any law for the time being in force in India, to be tried for an offence committed beyond India shall be dealt with according to the provisions of this Sanhita for any act committed beyond India in the same manner as if such act had been committed within India.

qas.question: What is the title of this Act?

answers.text: Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023.

qas.question: When does the Act come into force?

answers.text: On such date as the Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, appoint.

qas.question: Can different dates be appointed for different provisions of the Sanhita?

answers.text: Yes, different dates may be appointed for different provisions of this Sanhita.

qas.question: Who is liable to punishment under the Sanhita?

answers.text: Every person shall be liable to punishment under this Sanhita and not otherwise for every act or omission contrary to the provisions thereof, of which he shall be guilty within India.

qas.question: How are offences committed beyond India dealt with under this Sanhita?

answers.text: According to the provisions of this Sanhita for any act committed beyond India in the same manner as if such act had been committed within India.

paragraphs.context: The provisions of this Sanhita shall also apply to any offence committed by any citizen of India in any place without and beyond India; any person on any ship or aircraft registered in India wherever it may be; any person in any place without and beyond India committing offence targeting a computer resource located in India.

qas.question: To whom does the Sanhita apply for offences committed beyond India?

answers.text: Any citizen of India in any place without and beyond India.

qas.question: Does the Sanhita apply to offences committed on Indian ships or aircraft?

answers.text: Yes, it applies to any person on any ship or aircraft registered in India wherever it may be.

qas.question: What offences targeting computer resources are covered under the Sanhita?

answers.text: Any person in any place without and beyond India committing offence targeting a computer resource located in India.
