paragraphs.context: In this Sanhita, unless the context otherwise requires, 'act' denotes as well a series of acts as a single act; 'animal' means any living creature, other than a human being; 'child' means any person below the age of eighteen years; 'counterfeit' means a person who causes one thing to resemble another thing, intending by means of that resemblance to practise deception, or knowing it to be likely that deception will thereby be practised.

qas.question: What does the term 'act' denote under the Sanhita?

answers.text: A series of acts as a single act.

qas.question: How is 'animal' defined in this Sanhita?

answers.text: Any living creature, other than a human being.

qas.question: Who is considered a 'child' under this Sanhita?

answers.text: Any person below the age of eighteen years.

qas.question: What does 'counterfeit' mean under this Sanhita?

answers.text: A person who causes one thing to resemble another thing, intending by means of that resemblance to practise deception, or knowing it to be likely that deception will thereby be practised.

paragraphs.context: The Sanhita defines 'Court' as a Judge who is empowered by law to act judicially alone, or a body of Judges which is empowered by law to act judicially as a body, when such Judge or body of Judges is acting judicially; 'death' means the death of a human being unless the contrary appears from the context; 'dishonestly' means doing anything with the intention of causing wrongful gain to one person or wrongful loss to another person.

qas.question: How is 'Court' defined in the Sanhita?

answers.text: A Judge who is empowered by law to act judicially alone, or a body of Judges which is empowered by law to act judicially as a body, when such Judge or body of Judges is acting judicially.

qas.question: What does 'death' mean in the context of this Sanhita?

answers.text: The death of a human being unless the contrary appears from the context.

qas.question: What is meant by 'dishonestly' in the Sanhita?

answers.text: Doing anything with the intention of causing wrongful gain to one person or wrongful loss to another person.

paragraphs.context: The Sanhita defines a 'document' as any matter expressed or described upon any substance by means of letters, figures or marks, or by more than one of those means, and includes electronic and digital record, intended to be used, or which may be used, as evidence of that matter.

qas.question: What is the definition of a 'document' in this Sanhita?

answers.text: Any matter expressed or described upon any substance by means of letters, figures or marks, or by more than one of those means, and includes electronic and digital record, intended to be used, or which may be used, as evidence of that matter.

paragraphs.context: Theft is snatching if, in order to commit theft, the offender suddenly or quickly or forcibly seizes or secures or grabs or takes away from any person or from his possession any movable property.

qas.question: What defines theft as snatching?

answers.text: If the offender suddenly or quickly or forcibly seizes or grabs or takes away movable property from any person or from their possession.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits snatching, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing snatching?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits theft in any building, tent or vessel used as a human dwelling or used for the custody of property; or of any means of transport used for the transport of goods or passengers; or of any article or goods from any means of transport used for the transport of goods or passengers; or of idol or icon in any place of worship; or of any property of the Government or of a local authority, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for theft in a dwelling, transport, place of worship, or government property?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being a clerk or servant, or being employed in the capacity of a clerk or servant, commits theft in respect of any property in the possession of his master or employer, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for theft committed by a clerk or servant?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
